channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Heavy Barrage of Rockets From Gaza Hits Southern Israel
item.description: The militant group Islamic Jihad claimed responsibility for the rocket attack, the most intense barrage since the ceasefire of 2012.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Challenges Ahead for Pope Francis as He Enters Second Year
item.description: Widely praised and globally popular, Francis has raised expectations that he will bring major changes to the Roman Catholic Church.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Pope Francis, pictured on March 5, marks the first anniversary of his papacy on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Offering a German Lesson for Asia’s History Wars
item.description: Nearly 70 years after the end of World War II, China and Japan are still verbally and symbolically battling over wartime traumas that have long been resolved in Europe.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times

item.title: Cancale Journal: In France, a Quest to Convert a Sea Snail Plague Into a Culinary Pleasure
item.description: The community of Cancale now finds itself torn between disgust and relief at an entrepreneur’s project to fish and sell the sea snails for consumption.
item.dc:creator: By LALITA CLOZEL
item.media:credit: Catalina Martin-Chico for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jean-François Dore raked up the Atlantic slipper shells that cover the seabed in the waters off Cancale in France in an attempt to protect the area’s oyster and mussel farms from the invasive sea snails.

item.title: Russia Reins In Another News Organization
item.description: A popular independent online news site, Lenta.ru, got a warning from the government about its Ukraine coverage, and then a new editor.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: Leading Ukraine, a Technocrat Encircled by Problems
item.description: Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk, a veteran of Ukrainian politics who was vaulted into the role of acting prime minister after the Kiev uprising, is beset by challenges from Russia, Crimea and internal rivals.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk, Ukraine's interim prime minister, during a European Union summit last week in Brussels.

item.title: Israel Restricts Exemptions From Military Service
item.description: After years of heated debate, Parliament approved legislation to phase out exemptions for ultra-Orthodox students at religious seminaries.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: On March 2, hundreds of thousands of ultra-Orthodox brought much of Jerusalem to a standstill with a mass prayer gathering to protest the legislation.

item.title: Radar Blips Baffle Officials in Malaysian Jet Inquiry
item.description: Malaysian authorities were struggling to interpret radar signals showing what could be the missing jet veering off course and hundreds of miles from its last known position.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER and MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Malaysian shaman performed a ceremony they claim will help locate the missing jet.

item.title: Bangladesh Inspections Find Gaps in Safety
item.description: Nearly a year after the collapse of a factory building killed more than 1,100 workers, reports released on Tuesday detail problems at 10 other factories.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The April 2013 collapse of a textile factory outside Dhaka, Bangladesh.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: March 12
item.description: A protest march in McLeodganj town in Himachal Pradesh on the 55th anniversary of the Tibetan National Uprising Day against Chinese rule.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Tibetan women and children attending a peaceful protest march in McLeodganj town in Himachal Pradesh to mark the 55th anniversary of the Tibetan National Uprising Day against Chinese rule.

item.title: Kerry Plans 11th-Hour Meeting With Russians Over Crimea
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry will meet the Russian foreign minister in London two days before Crimeans vote in a referendum on joining Russia.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: “There are a lot of variants here, which is why it is urgent that we have this conversation with the Russians,” Secretary of State John Kerry said.

item.title: Plane’s Locating Device Went Silent Before Disappearance
item.description: One of the mysteries surrounding Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 concerns the aircraft’s transponder, which apparently stopped functioning about 40 minutes into the flight.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW L. WALD

item.title: Ukraine’s Interim Leader Seeks Aid in Washington
item.description: Ukraine’s interim prime minister, Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk, met Wednesday with President Obama and Secretary of State John Kerry at a critical moment for his country.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: President Obama met with Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk, the interim prime minister of Ukraine, in the Oval Office on Wednesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Outburst by Prominent Party Official Reverberates Online
item.description: Reports that Wang Qishan, one of China’s most senior political figures, had upbraided the Communist Party secretary of Jilin Province at a closed-door meeting seemed to offer a rare glimpse into the internal dynamics of elite party politics.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: Wang Qishan, secretary of the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection.

item.title: India Ink: Two Maharashtra Parties Compete for National Party’s Affections
item.description: Uddhav Thackeray of the Shiv Sena and Raj Thackeray, leader of a rival party, are engaged in a power struggle that has far-reaching implications for one of the oldest political alliances in the state’s history.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Raj Thackeray, chief of Maharashtra Navnirman Sena, a regional political party in Maharashtra, in Mumbai on Sept. 11, 2008.

item.title: Lens Blog: An Uncertain Quiet for Crimean Tatars
item.description: More than 20 years after her family returned from decades of exile to their Crimean roots, Emine Ziyatdinova wonders if the upheaval in Crimea will again force Tatars from their homeland.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID GONZALEZ
item.media:description: Dinner at Abdul' Seit-Ametov house. Mr. Seit-Ametov is Crimean Tatar artist working with traditional ceramics and ornaments.

item.title: On Ukraine, Merkel Finds Limits of Her Rapport With Putin
item.description: With Chancellor Angela Merkel failing to sway President Vladimir V. Putin on the crisis, Germans are wondering whether their policy of conciliation with Russia has run its course.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany has tried to nudge President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia toward an offramp in the crisis over Ukraine.

item.title: British Opposition Leader Cool to Quick Vote on E.U. Membership
item.description: Ed Miliband, the leader of the Labour Party, reduced the prospects of Britain leaving the 28-nation European Union in the next few years.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: India Ink: Before Elections, Mumbai Snack Turns Into a Political Hot Potato
item.description: The Shiv Sena, the Hindu nationalist party that dominates the city’s government, is quietly helping voters set up stalls to sell the street food vada pav in return for their support.
item.dc:creator: By MANSI CHOKSI
item.media:description: A stall affiliated with the Shiv Sena party selling vada pav, a popular snack in Mumbai.

item.title: World Briefing: Nepal: Push to Open Peaks to Climbers
item.description: The government is considering contracts with climbing companies that would grant exclusive access to many of its highest mountains, a spokesman for Nepal’s tourism ministry said on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: World Briefing: El Salvador: Demonstrators Blocked at Count of Vote in Presidential Runoff
item.description: The police blocked hundreds of supporters of the conservative candidate in El Salvador’s presidential election from reaching a hotel where the authorities were doing a final count Monday for the runoff contest.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Suit Filed in Haiti Cholera Epidemic
item.description: A class-action lawsuit claiming to represent cholera victims in Haiti and their relatives in the United States was filed against the United Nations on Tuesday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: World Briefing: Italy: Guilty Verdicts in Rendition Case
item.description: The country’s highest court upheld guilty verdicts against the three United States defendants in the 2003 extraordinary rendition kidnapping of Osama Moustafa Hassan Nasr.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Gaza: Explosives in a House Kill 3
item.description: An explosion on Tuesday at a house in Beit Hanoun, a town in the northern Gaza Strip, killed three people and wounded at least seven others, the Gaza Ministry of Health said.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM

item.title: Wanted by Ecuador, 2 Brothers Make Mark in U.S. Campaigns
item.description: Political donations by relatives of Roberto and William Isaias, fugitives from Ecuador who fled to Miami, have raised questions about Washington’s decision making on their fate.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:credit: Angel Valentin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Roberto Isaias, who has withstood extradition requests from Ecuador, in Miami last month.
